conclusion: Determine the magnitude and direction of the force exerted by the small ball on the light rod at the highest point P while the slider is locked.
The gravitational force mg acts downward on the ball at point P.
The tension force F from the rod acts along the rod towards the center of the circular path.
At point P, the net force towards the center must provide the centripetal force required for circular motion.
The centripetal force is given by mv^2/L, where v is the speed of the ball at point P.
Set up the equation F + mg = mv^2/L for centripetal force.
Use conservation of mechanical energy to determine the speed v at point P.
Initial energy is 1/2mv_0^2 and energy at point P is 1/2mv^2 + mgL.
Simplify to find v^2: v_0^2 = v^2 + 2gL, thus v^2 = v_0^2 - 2gL.
Substitute the given values v_0 = 4 m/s and L = 0.5 m to find v^2 = 6.
Substitute v^2 into the centripetal force equation: F + mg = mv^2/L.
Solve F + 10 = 12 to find F = 2 N.
The magnitude of the force exerted by the small ball on the light rod is 2 N and the direction is downward.
